utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

Director Comey said that my answers were truthful and what I've said is consistent with what I have told the American people, that there were decisions discussed and made to classify retroactively certain of the emails.
But that's not accurate.
I mean, Comey said there's no evidence she lied to the FBI, but that's not the same as saying she told the truth to the American people.
This seems like something that could have gone away, but it hasn't.
Why would Hillary Clinton make this blunder?
Quickly, E.J.
Well, I mean, if this is a lie, they are nothing compared to the ones Trump says every day.
I think she wants to defend herself so much that she goes into more detail on this than she should.
All she needs to say is the FBI investigated.
They cleared me.
They didn't bring charges.
Let's move on.
And she's got to learn just to say that.
David.
Yeah.
It may not be as big as Trump lies, though it is a lie.
She definitely sent classified emails.
Comey said that in congressional testimony, definitely used different servers, things she denied in public.
So she's been dishonest about that, and her own wall of suspicion is still her great weakness.
But she's had the virtue of being boring this week compared to Mr. Trump.
That's David Brooks of The New York Times, and E.J.
Dionne of The Washington Post.
Thanks to both of you.
Good to be with you.
Thank you.
Rental markets are hot in so many places, and people just don't seem as eager to own a home.
For the national picture, we turn to David Wessel.
He's director of the Hutchins Center at the Brookings Institution and a contributing correspondent to The Wall Street Journal.
We began with why rents are increasing so dramatically.
Well, it's pretty simple.
Supply isn't keeping up with demand.
Over the past year, the number of renters rose by 2 million while the number of homeowning families in the U.S.
fell by 400,000.
So you got more people wanting to rent, and they're not building enough rental units to accommodate that, so the rents go up.
OK, so demand is really at play here.
Let's figure out why demand is going up.
Why are more people choosing to rent over, say, buying a house?
I think there are a number of things at play here.
One is a lot of people were burned in the housing market over the last few years.
People now realize that housing prices can go down as well as up, and that's made some of them uneasy about buying.

Some of the newly-formed households - young people graduating from college are finally moving out of their parents' basements - are finding that their jobs are too low to buy houses at today's prices, even though mortgage rates are low.
And it's particularly hard for first- time homebuyers and anybody who has less than a stellar credit record to get a mortgage.
It's getting a little easier, but that's still a big obstacle.
NPR's Jim Zarroli is covering this story from New York.
Hi, Jim.
My name is Mandy Rivers.
I'm from Columbia, South Carolina.
And a girlfriend of mine and her fiance have been having lots of pre-wedding functions.
And she had sent out an email inviting all of the ladies to yet another pre-wedding function.
And I clicked on reply to all, so the email that I sent went to her as well as all of my friends.
And the email said that I would rather stab myself in the eye than to attend.
You know, the plans were that I would be in the wedding and I was asked not to be and I've not heard from her since.
And not terribly surprising, huh, Steve?
Well, you know, I'd rather stab myself in the eye than have that happen to me, but, you know...
Well, we also heard from some of you on another subject.
Derrick Hunter, he's the Ohio man who needs two SUVs to accommodate his kids and is struggling to pay the gas bills.
Rick Hawkins wrote from Durham, North Carolina to say it was so ironic to hear Derrick Hunter say that he needed an SUV to take his family to see the Amish Country.
Apparently that visit did not remind him that for many millennia families of all sizes managed just fine without SUVs.
Although there was that six-wheel, 14-passenger Conestoga wagon that people liked at that time.
We had a correction this morning.
I said earlier this week that SUV owner Derrick Hunter lived in Lima, Ohio.
That was during some early feeds of this program.
Turns out I was wrong about the pronunciation, and we got the right pronunciation from this man.
Well, my name is David Berger.
I serve as the mayor of the city of Lima, Ohio.
Our name was chosen actually in 1831 when this part of the state was a large, swampy area that had a severe problem with malaria.
And folks in this area have imported quinine from Lima, Peru and they chose the name.
However, they also made a very deliberate choice to pronounce the name with a long I.
So it's certainly an acknowledgment of the heritage that we were given from South America, but it's also a uniquely Ohio pronunciation.
(Soundbite of song, ""Let's Call the Whole Thing Off"")
(Singing) You like vanilla and I like vanilla, you sarsaparilla and I sarsaparilla, vanilla, vanilla...
And if you'd like to send your comments on something you hear on this program, that would just feen(ph) with us.
You can do it by going to NPR.org and click on Contact Us.
(Soundbite of song, ""Let's Call the Whole Thing Off"")
Forget the election.
This is the night that college basketball begins its season.
The defending men's NCAA champion is the University of Florida, which has most of its key players back.
Commentator John Feinstein will be watching the season and joins us now.
Good morning again, John.
Good morning, Steve.
Any chance Florida could repeat?
There is a good chance Florida could repeat.
Now, doing that is extremely difficult in college basketball, since John Wooden's run of 10 titles in 12 years at UCLA ended in 1975.
Only Duke in 1991 and '92 has won back-to-back NCAA titles.

But Florida has the ingredients, because as you mentioned, most of their key players opted not to go on the NBA draft - notably Joakim Noah, their sophomore center, who was the best player in the country last March.
And because of that, Billy Donovan, the coach, has his nucleus back to try to defend that title.
So they've got a legitimate shot if they stay healthy.
How did Donovan persuade his players to stay?
That's a very good question, because the trend is, you know, is completely the opposite.
Look at what North Carolina, when they won the national championship in 2005 and four underclassmen jumped to the NBA.
That's the way it usually is.
But interestingly, Noah of course is the son of Yannick Noah, the tennis player who made a lot of money as a professional tennis player.

So it's not like turning pro means he gets to buy his mom a house, which is often the motivator for some of these kids who don't grow up with money, who want to get to their first professional contract.
So Florida's got a strong team.
Who are the other serious contenders?
Well, North Carolina is back after last year when they had to play mostly freshmen.
Now they've got a great sophomore class and another strong freshman class and they're certainly a team to watch.
Kansas - which has been a disappointment loosing in the first round of the NCAA tournament the last two years - has a lot of their key players back.
But you know what's interesting, Steve?

Last year, if you go back and play the tape of our preseason conversation, I will almost guarantee you that I never mentioned Florida, UCLA, LSU, or George Mason, and they were last year's final four.
Wow.
And...
Which either shows you that I know nothing about basketball, or it's our most unpredictable sport, because I wasn't the only one who was a 100 percent wrong a year ago.
Somewhere, somebody's firing off an e-mail right now, offering their answer to that option, John.
But in any case, it is an unpredictable sport, and it remains a popular sport even though there doesn't seem to be - as you mentioned - a dynasty of any kind at this time.
You know what I think?

If you were to play this era's best college teams against the best college teams of 20 or 30 years ago, the teams of 20 or 30 years ago would win easily because they were juniors and seniors and the kids knew how to play fundamentals.
They knew how to box out, none of which basketball players do today.
But even in spite of that, the game is as competitive as it ever was.
A George Mason can emerge and be a Cinderella story.
You have teams form smaller conferences that get to the sweet 16, the way Wichita State and Bradley did out of the Missouri Valley last year.
You don't know.
It's not like college football where you and I can sit down and make a list of 10 teams every year and almost for sure, one of those teams will be the national champion.
You can't do that in college basketball.
One other story we're watching early in the season, John.
Your old friend Bob Knight is on the brink of a record.
Hi, Steve.
We're going to take a moment now to tell you what we know about some of the victims of yesterday's massacre.
The shooting began in a dorm, and the two students who died there were Ryan Clark and Emily Hilscher.
He was 22 years old, a month away from graduation with a triple major in psychology, biology and English, and a member of the Marching Virginians pep band.
She was a 19-year-old freshman known as an animal lover in her hometown of Woodville, Virginia.
In fact, she was studying animal and poultry sciences.
On MySpace, she wrote that she's interested, in her words, in pretty much everything except history.

Thirty people were gunned down in a classroom building, among them students Matthew La Porte from Dumont, New Jersey; Henry Lee, who was 20 and who grew up in Roanoke, Virginia; and Reema Samaha, an 18-year-old freshmen from Centerville, Virginia.
She and the shooter attended the same high school but apparently did not know each other.
